rev.diff:
Line 47: Line 47:
===Closure===
===Closure===
At the time of its closure in November 1996, the brewery had a 1.3 million barrel capacity and employed 184 people, although this was down from around 250 in the brewery's heyday.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/scottish--newcastle-to-cut-1600-brewing-jobs-1324420.html |title=Scottish & Newcastle to cut 1,600 brewing jobs â Business, News â The Independent |author=Nigel Cope|work=[[The Independent]] |date=17 January 1996 |publisher=[[Independent News & Media|INM]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0951-9467 |oclc=185201487 |accessdate=15 April 2011}}</ref><ref>http://www.competition-commission.org.uk/rep_pub/reports/1990/fulltext/288c5.pdf</ref><ref name="halifaxcourier2">{{cite web|author=Published on Fri Nov 13 14:37:19 GMT 2009 |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/business/bringing_a_history_of_brewing_back_to_life_1_1941260 |title=Bringing a history of brewing back to life â Business |publisher=Halifax Courier |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> As well as Webster's, a large amount of lager had been brewed there, particularly ''[[Holsten]]'' and ''[[Budweiser]]'', the latter of which it had been the first to brew in the UK in 1984.<ref name=warc/><ref name="halifaxcourier2"/> Following the closure, Webster's beers were initially brewed at Scottish Courage's John Smith's brewery in [[Tadcaster]], but were subsequently moved to the Thomas Hardy Brewery at [[Burtonwood]].<ref>http://www.spbw.com/magazine/PiH%2097.pdf</ref> [[Scottish & Newcastle]] continued to provide funding for an annual former employees' [[Christmas lunch]] until 2004.<ref>{{cite web|author=Published on Mon Dec 28 07:41:46 GMT 2009 |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/local/calderdale_life_wee_sam_lunch_proves_to_be_as_popular_as_ever_1_1943290 |title=Calderdale Life: Wee Sam lunch proves to be as popular as ever â Local |publisher=Halifax Courier |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> With their acquisition of the UK arm of Scottish & Newcastle, [[Heineken]] is the brand owner.<ref>Samuel Webster company is registed to the firm that Heineken UK always use.</ref>
At the time of its closure in November 1996, the brewery had a 1.3 million barrel capacity and employed 184 people, although this was down from around 250 in the brewery's heyday.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/scottish--newcastle-to-cut-1600-brewing-jobs-1324420.html |title=Scottish & Newcastle to cut 1,600 brewing jobs â Business, News â The Independent |author=Nigel Cope|work=[[The Independent]] |date=17 January 1996 |publisher=[[Independent News & Media|INM]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0951-9467 |oclc=185201487 |accessdate=15 April 2011}}</ref><ref>http://www.competition-commission.org.uk/rep_pub/reports/1990/fulltext/288c5.pdf</ref><ref name="halifaxcourier2">{{cite web|author=Published on Fri Nov 13 14:37:19 GMT 2009 |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/business/bringing_a_history_of_brewing_back_to_life_1_1941260 |title=Bringing a history of brewing back to life â Business |publisher=Halifax Courier |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> As well as Webster's, a large amount of lager had been brewed there, particularly ''[[Holsten]]'' and ''[[Budweiser]]'', the latter of which it had been the first to brew in the UK in 1984.<ref name=warc/><ref name="halifaxcourier2"/> Following the closure, Webster's beers were initially brewed at Scottish Courage's John Smith's brewery in [[Tadcaster]], but were subsequently moved to the Thomas Hardy Brewery at [[Burtonwood]].<ref>http://www.spbw.com/magazine/PiH%2097.pdf</ref> [[Scottish & Newcastle]] continued to provide funding for an annual former employees' [[Christmas lunch]] until 2004.<ref>{{cite web|author=Published on Mon Dec 28 07:41:46 GMT 2009 |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/local/calderdale_life_wee_sam_lunch_proves_to_be_as_popular_as_ever_1_1943290 |title=Calderdale Life: Wee Sam lunch proves to be as popular as ever â Local |publisher=Halifax Courier |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> With their acquisition of the UK arm of Scottish & Newcastle, [[Heineken]] is the brand owner.<ref>Samuel Webster company is registed to the firm that Heineken UK always use.</ref>
â
[[Image:Websters.jpg|thumb|left|''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' brand is now owned by [[Heineken International]]]]
